articles.headline: Flint Is in the News, but Lead Poisoning Is Even Worse in Cleveland
articles.snippet: Four decades ago, political leaders declared war on lead, citing evidence of its pernicious impact on young brains. But the crusade remains unfinished.
articles.abstract: Four decades ago, political leaders declared war on lead, citing evidence of its pernicious impact on young brains. But the crusade remains unfinished.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — One hundred fifty miles northwest of here, the residents of Flint, Mich., are still reeling from the drinking water debacle that more than doubled the share of children with elevated levels of lead in their blood — to a peak, in mid-2014, of 7 percent of all children tested.

articles.headline: Republicans Have a Stake in Making a Deal on a Supreme Court Justice
articles.snippet: Given recent poll numbers and the chance that they may lose the Senate, Republicans might want to consider an Obama nominee for the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Given recent poll numbers and the chance that they may lose the Senate, Republicans might want to consider an Obama nominee for the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senate Republican leaders have insisted they won’t consider an Obama nominee to the Supreme Court, leaving that choice to the next president. But they may want to reconsider after this week — especially if they care about protecting the pro-business rulings that are among the late Justice Antonin Scalia’s most important legacies.

articles.headline: Apple Is Rolling Up Backers in iPhone Privacy Fight Against F.B.I.
articles.snippet: Apple’s legal battle with the government tests the limits of law enforcement agencies’ access to personal data.
articles.abstract: Apple’s legal battle with the government tests the limits of law enforcement agencies’ access to personal data.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google, Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft and a parade of other technology companies filed a barrage of court briefs on Thursday, aiming to puncture the United States government’s legal arguments against Apple in a case that will test the limits of the authorities’ access to personal data.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Law Firm’s First Latina Partner, With Boost From N.Y.U. Program
articles.snippet: The AnBryce program aims to give students from disadvantaged backgrounds the financial and networking support needed to succeed in school and beyond.
articles.abstract: The AnBryce program aims to give students from disadvantaged backgrounds the financial and networking support needed to succeed in school and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a young girl helping her parents run their Brooklyn bodega, Damaris Hernández would not have dared to dream that she would one day become a lawyer, let alone a partner in one of world’s most rarefied legal firms.

articles.headline: Aubrey McClendon, Restless and Reckless Wildcatter, Was Deal-Making to the End
articles.snippet: Mr. McClendon, who died in a car crash a day after being indicted on bid-rigging charges, was trying to expand globally the shale boom he pioneered.
articles.abstract: Mr. McClendon, who died in a car crash a day after being indicted on bid-rigging charges, was trying to expand globally the shale boom he pioneered.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the days leading up to Aubrey McClendon’s death in a car crash on Wednesday, the pressure on him had become unrelenting.

articles.headline: Pension Benefit Cuts Planned at T.V.A., Breaking a Federal Firewall
articles.snippet: Workers and retirees at the Tennessee Valley Authority may see their benefits cut even as executives spare their own supplemental pension plan.
articles.abstract: Workers and retirees at the Tennessee Valley Authority may see their benefits cut even as executives spare their own supplemental pension plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Politicians in states around the country have moved in recent years to rein in the pensions of government employees, which in many cases had become more generous and less risky than those of their private sector counterparts.

articles.headline: In Republican Debate, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Wage Urgent Attacks on Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Mr. Rubio and Mr. Cruz relentlessly demeaned and denounced Mr. Trump at Thursday’s debate, all but pleading with Republicans to reconsider nominating him.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rubio and Mr. Cruz relentlessly demeaned and denounced Mr. Trump at Thursday’s debate, all but pleading with Republicans to reconsider nominating him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get live updates about the Florida primary.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Boko Haram Falls Victim to a Food Crisis It Created
articles.snippet: Across northeastern Nigeria and bordering Cameroon, farmers have fled, herdsmen have rerouted cattle drives, and markets have shut down.
articles.abstract: Across northeastern Nigeria and bordering Cameroon, farmers have fled, herdsmen have rerouted cattle drives, and markets have shut down.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORA, Cameroon — At first, the attack had all the hallmarks of a typical Boko Haram assault. Armed fighters stormed a town on the border with Nigeria, shooting every man they saw.

articles.headline: Jobs Report Shows Brisk U.S. Hiring in February
articles.snippet: The government said employers added 242,000 workers last month, highlighting the labor market’s steady gains. Unemployment remained at 4.9 percent.
articles.abstract: The government said employers added 242,000 workers last month, highlighting the labor market’s steady gains. Unemployment remained at 4.9 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: With anxiety about the economy bubbling up on Wall Street and at campaign rallies around the country, the government reported on Friday that employers added 242,000 workers in February, a hefty increase that highlighted the labor market’s steady gains.
